results.name: Nadia Tass
results.description: Comedic and cult classics take centre stage in Nadia Tass' career.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Nadia Tass
key_work.brief_description: A film director, producer and actress, originally from Florina, Macedonia, northern Greece, who moved to Australia in the 1960s. She began her career as an actress appearing in the television series Prisoner (1979–86) Her first feature film was the now iconic Malcolm (1986).

links.description: Nadia Tass’ first feature film is the cult classic Australian comedy Malcolm, which she made with her husband David Parker. The film won the AFI Award for Best Film, along with seven other awards including Best Director and Best Script.

links.description: After The Big Steal, and her two previous Australian comedies, Tass directed the American film Pure Luck, a vehicle for Martin Short about a clumsy, luckless man tasked with finding a similarly luckless woman who has been kidnapped.

links.description: Tass has since commented that the film is not “satisfying”, pointing out the differences in Australian and American humour, and that she and Short’s co-star, Danny Glover, wanted to do something different. Glover got his chance in another mismatched buddy movie with an Australian, Lethal Weapon with Mel Gibson.

end.title: The Simpsons
end.brief_description: Set in Springfield, the average American town, the show focuses on the antics and everyday adventures of the Simpson family; Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and Maggie, as well as a virtual cast of thousands. Since the beginning, the series has been a pop culture icon, attracting hundreds of celebrities to guest star. The show has also made name for itself in its fearless satirical take on politics, media and American life in general.

constellations_other.name: Migrations
constellations_other.description: Universal Everything's Migrations features fantastical creatures born from elements of other animals, just like the titles in this Constellation.

constellations_other.name: Oh, no! Beta!
constellations_other.description: The Sony Betacam BVP-3P was a broadcast-quality camera that used Sony's Beta system, most commonly found in consumer cameras. During the Format Wars in the 1970s and 80s, Beta lost to the cheaper and more accessible Video Home System (VHS).

constellations_other.name: Transformations
constellations_other.description: Like many techniques born from the visual language of magic lanterns, the dissolve effect was incorporated into filmmaking and is still used today.

constellations_other.name: Cartoon classics and criticism
constellations_other.description: A whole cavalcade of cartoons have successfully made the leap into arcades and onto consoles, but the relationship between cinema and videogames is far more likely to fizzle out.

constellations_other.description: Comedic and cult classics take centre stage in Nadia Tass' career.

links.description: The kidnapper in Pure Luck is Frank Grimes. If that name sounds familiar, it’s because of The Simpsons’ episode ‘Homer’s Enemy’, where a new employee to the power plant, Frank Grimes, suffers because of Homer’s carelessness and clumsiness, much like the Grimes in Pure Luck.

end.title: Prisoner
end.creator_credit: Marie Trevor and Reg Grundy Productions
end.brief_description: Created by Reg Watson and screening a total of 692 episodes between 1979 and 1986, “Prisoner” was one of the first television series to tackle issues such as rape, homosexuality and violence. It did this through the relationships between a cross section of women and the women who work around them at the Wentworth Detention Centre. This groundbreaking serial funded by the Grundy Organisation was screened in countries throughout the world and was remade in Germany and the U.K. The complete title of the series overseas was “Prisoner: Cell block H”. PLEASE NOTE: the dates recorded in entries pertain to copyright year and usually preceeds the screening year.

end.title: Forrest Gump
end.creator_credit: Charles Newirth, Steve Starkey, Steve Tisch, Wendy Finerman and The Steve Tisch Company
end.brief_description: Tom Hanks stars as one of the most memorable characters in cinematic history, Forrest Gump, the big-hearted man who was there in the biggest moments in American history. Directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Eric Roth won six Academy Awards.

constellations_other.name: Quirky, eccentric, charming
constellations_other.description: The eponymous character of Malcolm (1986) is a kind and gentle young man obsessed with trams and making gadgets. Such charming and eccentric figures have a long lineage in screen history.

constellations_other.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_other.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

constellations_other.name: Nadia Tass
constellations_other.description: Comedic and cult classics take centre stage in Nadia Tass' career.

links.description: In Malcolm, Colin Friels’ portrayal suggests that Malcolm has high-functioning autism or Asperger syndrome. Another iconic character interpreted to have the same condition is Forrest Gump. David Parker has said he and Tass received the script for Forrest Gump but passed because “We’ve already done this.”

results.name: Fred Schepisi
results.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Fred Schepisi
key_work.brief_description: An Australian film director, producer and screenwriter. His credits include The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978), Plenty (1985), Roxanne (1987), Six Degrees of Separation (1993), Mr. Baseball (1992) and Last Orders (2001). Fred talks about his love for the craft and offers a perspective on violence.

end.title: The Devil's Playground

end.brief_description: The Devil’s Playground is a 1976 Australian drama film written, produced and directed by Fred Schepisi. It is a semi-autobiographical film which tells the story of a boy growing up and going to school in a Catholic juniorate administered by De La Salle Brothers.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi

links.description: Acclaimed Australian director Fred Schepisi’s first feature was The Devil’s Playground, a semi-autobiographical film about a boy growing up in a Catholic school. The film explores with the “myriad of ways men deal with sexual repression in the Catholic church”, according to film critic Luke Buckmaster.

end.title: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith
end.creator_credit: Brian Kavanagh, Fred Schepisi and The Film House
end.brief_description: Based on the Thomas Keneally novel, this is the fictionalised story of Jimmy Governor, who, in 1901 went on a rampage killing numerous white settlers. Deft characterisation and ironic detail combine to paint a bleak portrait of a bitterly racist society emerging as a federated nation. Starring Tommy Lewis in the title role with co-stars Ray Barrett and Jack Thompson.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

links.description: After his debut, Schepisi directed the controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith. The film follows an Indigenous man (Tom E Lewis), who murders a white family and goes into hiding. Though acclaimed at the time, it raises questions of whether white filmmakers should tell Indigenous stories.

end.title: Sweet Country
end.creator_credit: Warwick Thornton, Heather Wallace, David Jowsey, Greer Simpkin, Bunya Productions, Tony Cronin, David Tranter and Steven McGregor
end.brief_description: It’s 1929 on the vast, desert-like, Eastern Arrernte Nation lands that are now known as the Central Australian outback. Sam Kelly, a middle-aged Aboriginal man, works the land of a kind preacher, Fred Smith. After an ill-tempered bully arrives in town and Kelly kills him in self-defence, he and his wife go on the run as a posse gathers to hunt him down.

constellations_primary.name: Sweet Country
constellations_primary.description: Warwick Thornton’s feature film Sweet Country is based on the story of Wilaberta Jack, which was told to sound recordist David Tranter by his grandfather and translated into storyboards.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

constellations_other.name: Native Tongue
constellations_other.description: The lead single off her album of the same name, 'Native Tongue' saw artist Mo'Ju explore cultural identity through music, movement and striking visuals.

constellations_other.name: Outlawed
constellations_other.description: From The Story of the Kelly Gang to Sweet Country, this Constellation explores bushrangers, samurai and bandits.

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

links.description: Warwick Thornton’s Sweet Country has a similar premise: an Indigenous man kills a white stockman and goes on the run. However, Sam (Hamilton Morris) is a sympathetic character who kills only out of self-defense and Thornton, as a First Peoples director, is better suited to tell the story.

links.description: American audiences interpreted The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith as a western, which led to Schepisi being offered the chance to direct Barbarosa, starring Willie Nelson and Gary Busey, which kicked off Schepisi’s Hollywood career.

start.title: Empire Falls
start.creator_credit: Donna Zakowska, Fred Schepisi, William Teitler, Aspetuck Productions, HBO Films, Marc Platt Productions, Stuart Wurtzel and Richard Russo
start.brief_description: The humorous, poignant story of a declining New England town and its inhabitants, whose lives are deeply rooted in and influenced by the Knox River and its vacant mills, their class differences, and ghosts of the past.

end.title: Nobody's Fool

end.brief_description: Sully is a rascally ne’er-do-well approaching retirement age. While he is pressing a worker’s compensation suit for a bad knee, he secretly works for his nemesis, Carl, and flirts with Carl’s young wife Toby.

links.description: Empire Falls was the last time that legendary actor Paul Newman appeared on-screen. Philip Seymour Hoffman, who appears in Empire Falls, was also in Nobody’s Fool with Newman. Both are based on novels by Richard Russo.

end.brief_description: The story of an old Jewish widow named Daisy Werthan and her relationship with her black chauffeur, Hoke. From an initial mere work relationship grew in 25 years a strong friendship between the two very different characters in a time when those types of relationships where shunned.

links.description: After 60-year career, another legendary actor, Jessica Tandy, last appeared on-screen in Nobody’s Fool. Like Newman, Tandy was an Oscar winner, receiving the Academy Award for her performance in Driving Miss Daisy, directed by Schepisi’s contemporary, Australian Bruce Beresford.

links.description: After over 20 years directing dramas, comedies and even a sci-fi film, Schepisi turned his attention to TV with the 2005 miniseries Empire Falls, which won a Golden Globe for Best Miniseries or Television Film and received seven Emmy nominations.

results.name: Bob Connolly
results.description: Australian audiences just can't seem to get enough of exploring local governments, bureaucracy and politics, whether that's through documentaries or biting social satire.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Bob Connolly
key_work.brief_description: An Australian film director, cinematographer and author. He is best known for his documentaries produced over the past 30 years, including The Highlands Trilogy (1983) and Rats in the Ranks (1996). More recent films include Facing the Music (2001) and Mrs Carey’s Concert (2011).

end.brief_description: Documents the clash of two cultures that occurred in the 1930s when the people of the highlands of New Guinea encountered the first Europeans to enter their world. One of these Australians, Michael Leahy, took a movie camera with him.

links.description: Bob Connolly started his career as a journalist for the ABC, where he met his wife and future filmmaking partner Robin Anderson. Together they made First Contact, a documentary about gold-prospecting Australians who explored the New Guinea highlands in 1930, which was nominated for an Oscar.

links.description: Thirteen years after First Contact, the duo made the award-winning Rats in the Ranks, a documentary that followed the inner workings of the Leichardt council during Mayoral elections. Incumbent Larry Hand fights for re-election while other councillors vie for his job.

end.brief_description: Grass Roots is an Australian television series produced by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation between 2000 and 2003.The series is set around the fictional Arcadia Waters Council near Sydney, and was primarily a satirical look at the machinations of local government.

links.description: Larry Hand may not have been so popular with his fellow councillors, but he was popular with audiences. In Grass Roots, a satirical look at local government, the lead character of Col Dunkley (Geoff Morrell) is based on Hand.

end.creator_credit: Working Dog
end.brief_description: Set inside the offices of the “Nation Building Authority”, a newly created government organisation responsible for overseeing major infrastructure projects, Utopia explores that moment when bureaucracy and grand dreams collide.

links.description: The bureaucracy, backstabbing and petty politics of a local council are prime material for satire. Those kinds of absurdities also exist at the federal levels of government and are ridiculed in Utopia, a satire set inside the fictional Nation Building Authority department.

constellations_other.description: For decades, newsreel companies covered the news, providing weekly stories of current events, sport, and entertainment to audiences at the cinema, and establishing the format that would be taken up by television and the nightly news.

links.description: Utopia is one of the latest satirical programs produced by Working Dog Productions, who have also made sports, variety and game shows to name a few. One of their first critically acclaimed projects was the current affairs program satire, Frontline.

start.title: Frontline
start.brief_description: Frontline is an Australian comedy television series which satirised Australian television current affairs programmes and reporting. It ran for three series of 13 half-hour episodes and was broadcast on ABC TV in 1994, 1995 and 1997.

end.title: The Mad Max film series
end.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Mad Max’s super-powered vehicles, legendary characters and post-apocalyptic setting influenced everything from movies, manga and music videos to fashion, videogames and art, spawning enough parodies, homages and clones to fill a Thunderdome.

constellations_primary.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_primary.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

results.name: Action, emotion and videogames
results.description: More and more, videogames are beginning to favour emotion as much as action, just like their film and TV cousins.

results.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
results.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

key_work.title: Basically Black
key_work.brief_description: Basically Black combined comedy, activism and performing arts while reflecting the political struggles and organising of 1960s and 70s Redfern. The first TV program written and performed by an all-Indigenous cast, this groundbreaking program tackled racism and white paternalism through humour.

constellations_other.name: Sequins and sapphires
constellations_other.description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

end.brief_description: David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience.

end.title: Never Stop Riding
end.brief_description: Alec Baker, Peter Mungkuri and Mr Kunmanara Pompey are three senior artists and respected leaders from Indulkana community on the APY Lands, SA. As young men, they were renowned stockmen and in 2017 they coordinated a men’s camp at the local cattle station. Influenced by their ongoing love for cowboy and western films and country music, they created their own spaghetti western: Never Stop Riding.

results.name: Connecting through film
results.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

key_work.title: The Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive
key_work.brief_description: Koorie people record ourselves as a means of self-representation, to destroy stereotypes and to ensure that we are not erased. These films from the Koori Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive preserve our culture and kinship for future generations.

end.title: Bill Onus hosting Alcheringa
end.brief_description: To Bill Onus, sharing his culture was an act of resistance and reclamation of power. Through Forgotten People(1967) and Alcheringa (1962), Bill demonstrated his ongoing commitment to self-representation through screen culture.

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film

links.description: Bill Onus is one of the first known Aboriginal filmmakers with a recently discovered silent 1946 film credited to him. Bill documented Aboriginal life on film, and was a trailblazer in self-representation. Some films from his family archive feature in the Memory Garden display.

start.title: My Survival as an Aboriginal
start.creator_credit: Essie Coffey
start.credit_line: Courtesy the Coffey family and Martha Ansara / the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia / Ballad Films
start.brief_description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture to her community.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

end.brief_description: A documentary that tells the epic life story of Alfreda Glynn, 78-year-old Aboriginal woman, stills photographer, co-founder of the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA), and Imparja TV.

links.description: She Who Must Be Loved captures the life of director Erica Glynn’s mother; Freda Glynn. Glynn played an intrinsic role in Aboriginal media; including the establishment of CAAMA and Imparja. The film is a personal portrait that uncovers the history of the Glynn family.

links.description: Reality TV show Family Rules follows Daniella Rule and her nine daughters as they navigate their daily lives in Perth. The show gets up close and personal and paints a lively portrait of the Rule family through all their challenges and changes.

start.title: Bill Onus hosting Alcheringa
start.brief_description: To Bill Onus, sharing his culture was an act of resistance and reclamation of power. Through Forgotten People(1967) and Alcheringa (1962), Bill demonstrated his ongoing commitment to self-representation through screen culture.

end.credit_line: Courtesy the Coffey family and Martha Ansara / the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia / Ballad Films
end.brief_description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture to her community.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

links.description: Aunty Essie Coffey became the first Aboriginal woman to direct a documentary with My Survival as an Aboriginal. It’s one of the first times an Aboriginal person had determined how their community was portrayed - following the legacy of Uncle Bill Onus.

links.description: Gurrutu’mi Mala (My Connections) is an artwork by Gutiŋarra Yunupiŋu that conveys his connections to family and country. In the film, Yunupiŋu communicates in barrkungu wanga (language from a distance) which is a Yolngu sign language used in the Yirrkala community.

constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

links.description: My Brilliant Career was a brilliant start for Armstrong’s own career, with her first feature garnering Palm d’Or and Academy Award noms. It sticks to the feminist spirit of the Miles Franklin’s novel on which it’s based by featuring many women in key creative roles.

results.name: Setting the record straight
results.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

end.brief_description: Ivan Sen’s debut feature continues the story of one of his acclaimed short films, ‘Tears’. Two disaffected teenagers, Vaughn and Lena (played by non-professional actors Damian Pitt and Dannielle Hall), meet on the road as they flee their troubled backgrounds and head to the city.

links.description: Beneath Clouds follows two young people as they hitchhike through regional NSW. Vaughan has just escaped juvenile prison, and Lena is running from home. The two grapple with issues faced by many young First Nations people; identity, belonging and navigating colonial systems.
